summary: I am an Assistant Professor in International Relations at Radboud University. I research foreign policy decision-making, political communication, and military intervention. My research touches on the interlinkage of foreign policy choice, public and electoral discourses, and the instruments of state behavior (such as sanctions, no-fly zones, and military force). I also work on neoclassical realism and its contributions to international relations theory, as well as in multiple projects on teaching, research and knowledge exchange. I was previously a Postdoctoral Fellow for US Foreign Policy & Politics at the London School of Economics.

field of studies 1: Behavioural Economics and the Modern Economy
skills: ['International Economics', 'financial economics', 'Reporting & Analysis', 'Microsoft Office', 'Technical Presentations', 'Managing Others', 'Coaching', 'Data Analysis', 'cost benefit analysis', 'Macroeconomics', 'Stata', 'Statistics', 'Analysis', 'Microeconomics', 'Financial Economics', 'Economics', 'Policy Analysis', 'Public Policy', 'Econometrics', 'Policy']
summary:
I am an economist and a behavioural scientist. I am currently the Director of the Consumer Protection Research Initiative at Innovations for Poverty Action. The initiative tries to identify, diagnose and solve consumer protection risks in digital finance through new methods of data analysis and rigorous testing of solutions through impact evaluations. By working with regulators, financial service providers, and civil society, we are building solutions that will ensure consumers are well-protected from new risks that emerge alongside financial innovations. 

I have 16 years of applied economics experience working with governments, regulators, not-for-profit and commercial companies, using research to understand and solve problems. Although I've never been a formal academic, I try to keep well connected to academia. I am a Visiting Senior Fellow at the London School of Economics Department for Psychology and Behavioural Science. My work has been published in top finance, economics and marketing journals, presented at Harvard, MIT, Chicago Booth and LSE, and featured in The Financial Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Economist and The Chicago Booth Review.

skills: ['Teamwork', 'Project Planning', 'Pharmacoepidemiology', 'Pharmaceutical Industry', 'Outcomes Research', 'Meta-analysis', 'Sistematic Review', 'Pharmacoeconomics', 'Pharmacovigilance', 'Risk Management', 'Health Economics', 'HEOR', 'Oncology']
summary:
For more information visit my website
https://sites.google.com/view/franciscavargaslopes

Francisca Vargas Lopes is a Ph.D. Candidate at the Department of Public Health of the Erasmus Medical Center, in Rotterdam, having joint supervision from the Erasmus School of Economics. Her project is focused in conducting impact evaluation of health policies, specifically evaluating the effect in health and health care inequalities. She is studying the areas of mental health care, long-term care, health insurance coverage and cost-sharing.  

Francisca graduated as a Pharmacist (M.Pharm) from the Faculty of Pharmacy of the University of Lisbon in 2013. In 2017, she completed an MSc in International Health Policy and Health Economics at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE), in the UK. While in London Francisca has been a research assistant to Social Policy and Psychological and Behavioural Science departments at LSE and has had academic placements at the health care focused think-thank Nuffield Trust and at the Health Value for Money team of the National Audit Office.

As part of her working experience Francisca has performed the roles of Outcomes Consultant and Outcomes Research Manager, respectively in UK and Portuguese subsidiaries of multinational pharmaceutical industries. She has also spent time as an analyst and consultant at the Centre for Evidence-based Medicine of the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Lisbon.
